overview.short: Haemophilus species are small, pleomorphic Gram-negative short rods (coccobacilli) within the Pasteurellaceae, commonly colonizing the human upper respiratory tract and requiring enriched media for growth.
overview.clinical_context: Includes clinically important respiratory pathogens and mucosal colonizers; some species cause invasive disease and others cause sexually transmitted infections.

field_notes.Media Grown On: Many species require enriched media (e.g., Chocolate Agar) due to X (hemin) and/or V (NAD) factor requirements.
field_notes.Shape: Often described as pleomorphic coccobacilli; mapped to 'Short Rods' in this schema.
field_notes.Haemolysis: Variable across species; some are non-haemolytic while others can be haemolytic on Blood Agar.

key_differentiators.notes: Fastidious growth on enriched media supports Haemophilus over many common Gram-negative rods.
Oxidase positivity supports Haemophilus over oxidase-negative Enterobacterales.
Non-motility helps separate from many motile oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods.

common_confusions.reason: Same family (Pasteurellaceae) and similar small Gram-negative morphology; biochemical overlap.
Related Pasteurellaceae with overlapping growth requirements and phenotypes in some settings.

when_to_question_identification: Robust growth on MacConkey Agar argues against Haemophilus (most are inhibited).
Strong lactose fermentation on MacConkey suggests Enterobacterales rather than Haemophilus.
Motility and strong oxidase positivity with non-fastidious growth suggests Aeromonas/Vibrio rather than Haemophilus.

recommended_next_tests.test: X and V factor requirement (hemin and NAD)

recommended_next_tests.reason: Reliable genus and species identification for fastidious organisms.
